Evolving such a network (a network that selects the parents for the 
next g=
eneration) will be incredibly hard. This is because there is 
some intellig=
ence required to perform a good selection. In TBE the 
intelligence is the =
static fitness function, in Picbreeder it is the 
human intelligence. In fa=
ct, some pictures may be "in order" but 
still represent nothing. Perhaps s=
ome pattern recognition technique 
may be involved in the process, but this=
 is still not enough. 
But it is an interesting idea of NEAT controlling an=
other NEAT. A 
population of "selector" networks, each one running an evolu=
tion. 
This will take A LOT of CPU time, but it is good for experimenting 
=
with. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@...>=
 wrote:
>
> Ken,
> 
> You had talked (at length...) about the merits of the=
 human-chooser
> verses the goal-oriented evolution.  I'd like to weigh in =
on it a
> little and maybe throw in an idea for how to make things even mor=
e
> interesting...
> 
> First of all, there is always a goal.  In one case,=
 the goal is very
> strictly defined, in the other, it is more losely defin=
ed.  But 
there
> is still a 'goal'.  The goal in PicBreeder is 'makes me f=
eel good'
> which CAN be defined, it just has to be defined in terms of 
so=
mething
> we can't see, which is the neuron firing pattern in our brains.
>=
 
> My hypothesis, though, is that there is a pattern to our internal
> cho=
osing of what we like.  And I posit that it may be possible to
> LEARN it. =
 Meaning, create a 'chooser' network that also evolves
> 'interesting' imag=
es.
> 
> You see, I think that 'recognition' is a key element in deciding 
=
what
> to choose.  And I think that the method that we use to recognize 
or=
der
> vs. chaos could be modeled.  Sure, recognizing the difference 
betwee=
n
> two people's faces would be harder to model, but I think it would be
> =
fairly easy to learn to model the difference between chaos and 
order.
> 
>=
 I'm thinking you should be able to evolve a network that tends to
> choose=
 (rank higher) images of real-world things over images of
> random, unstruc=
tured noise.  You could take many image chunks the 
size
> of the PicBreede=
r output images, all of which have some kind of
> recognizability and pleas=
antness to them.  Then create a large 
number
> of counter-examples that ar=
e built out of unstructured randomness, 
be
> it pixels or blobs or arcs or=
 whatever.  Then evolve a network that
> consistently recognizes the 'pleas=
ing' images (ranks them highly) 
and
> recognizes the chaotic images as suc=
h and thereby ranks them lower.
> 
> When that's done, integrate it into th=
e PicBreeder app as 
a 'chooser'
> which evolves and evolves until somebody=
 shuts it down.  Whenever it
> finds something that it likes more than some=
 threshold, it 'saves' 
it.
>  When it likes something more than an even hi=
gher threshold, it
> publishes it.
> 
> I predict that there will be a swee=
t spot for complexity of the
> PicBreeder image generating networks.  For a=
 while, as complexity
> grows, the chooser network will rank the images hig=
her and higher.
> But I suspect that at some point, that trend will reverse=
.  The 
number
> of highly ranked images as a percentage of all evolved ima=
ges at a
> particular complexity level will get lower as the complexity ris=
es
> above that sweet spot.
> 
> I would also like to mention that combinin=
g such a 'general coolness
> chooser' with a goal-oriented chooser could be=
 quite interesting.  
The
> two could work together synergistically to help=
 walk the search 
space
> faster.  Problem may be to generate that chooser =
correctly to begin
> with.  But my instincts tell me that one that is evolv=
ed to find
> regularity in an image and finds 'pleasing' relationships betw=
een
> them, such as the one described above, would be adequate to use in
> =
conjunction with a goal-oriented evolution of the CPPN networks for
> who-k=
nows-what.  The reason I say that is that I suspect that the 
same
> 'regul=
arities' that make for a 'pleasing' image are the same
> characteristics th=
at lead to a functional CPPN network.  But I'm 
sure
> you would know bette=
r based on your experiences working with them.
> 
> Just thought I'd throw =
that out there for you to think about.
> -- 
> John Arrowwood

anlons Razor (dot) com

ttp://arrowwood.blogspot.com
